Most often when I get the hiccups, it's after I eat a bunch of food and then stand up suddenly.  I feel like it must be linked to the vomiting reflex, since that also involves the diaphragm.  Like the body goes OH NO WE MIGHT NEED TO VOMIT and activates the diaphragm, and then decides it wasn't an emergency after all, but the DIAPHRAGM GO!! signal is still happening, so you just end up with hiccups instead, this dumb glitch that persists until you can get your body to reset.  (For me, exhaling all the air from my lungs and swallowing as many small sips of water as I can [burping as necessary] until I can't hold my breath any longer usually works.  Perhaps something about starving the relevant muscles of oxygen?)

Maybe a hiccup is your body's way of scanning the whole body and sending the analyses to the brain.

We know a great deal about hiccups. So what is the explanation behind fuccups?

One reason why hiccups occur, is restricted digestion. That's a fancy way of saying that you ate some carbohydrate rich food, or something quite filling, but haven't drank any water. Your stomach and pancreas need water to produce the acid necessary to digest your food.
When you don't have enough water in your stomach to displace the acid; it can cause your stomach nerves to fire overwhelmingly, causing your diaphragm to contract violently in reaction to the nervous stimuli. From there, the mechanics are the same for all hiccups.
REMEDY: before eating any dry, or large meals, drink a glass of 75/25 orange juice and water solution, followed by your meal, followed by a single tall glass of straight water. Do not lay down for at least one hour after eating.
Enjoy less hiccups!

Hiccups are easily dealt with by breathing in a bag or holding your breath.  Which doesn't allow you to expel carbon dioxide.  The high levels of carbon dioxide cause muscles like the diaphragm to relax, halting the spasms you were experiencing.  Drinking water can also do it by interrupting the signal, or redistributing the contents of the stomach.  Given that the diaphragm is right over the stomach, it's not surprising that hiccups are a symptom of eating too quickly.

Hiccups have to do with the balance of your stomach.
Do you know how to burp at command? You take in air into your stomach by opening your epiglottis and expanding your rib cage, like when you breathe. You can then burp by putting pressure on your stomach, like when you're breathing out.

Another similar and fascinating story about babies involves their unorganized sleeping patterns. Normally, children and adults have a so-called circadian rythm which makes us tired at night and involves the production of proteins depending on the presence/absence of sunlight among other factors. In babies, however, these proteins are not produced in a normal fashion yet and, therefore, they sometimes fall asleep at random times. It all normalises after a few months though (would love to make a video about this myself!). Since I'm a human biologist conducting stem cell research feel free to ask me anything about these topics!
